sn35.69:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca upaseno rājagahe viharanti sītavane sappasoṇḍikapabbhāre.
sn35.69:1.1.eng: At one time the venerables Sāriputta and Upasena were staying near Rājagaha in the Cool Grove, under the Snake’s Hood Grotto.
sn35.69:1.1.comm: The commentary says this was Upasena son of Vaṅgantā, Sāriputta’s younger brother. When newly ordained, he made the mistake of ordaining students too early (Kd 1:31.3.2), but later developed an impressive following (Bu NP 15:1.1.9), leading the Buddha to declare him the foremost of those who were “impressive all around” (AN 1.213). His song of triumph is recorded at Ud 4.9, while his verses at Thag 10.6 focus on contentment and humility.

sn35.69:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato upasenassa kāye āsīviso patito hoti.
sn35.69:1.2.eng: Now at that time a viper fell on Upasena’s body.

sn35.69:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upaseno bhikkhū āmantesi:

sn35.69:1.4.pli: “etha me, āvuso, imaṃ kāyaṃ mañcakaṃ āropetvā bahiddhā nīharatha.
sn35.69:1.4.eng: “Come, reverends, lift this body onto a cot and carry it outside
sn35.69:1.4.comm: This illustrates the difference between bāhira (“exterior”) and bahiddha (“external, outside”). Bāhira is the outside of an organism or a single thing (such as an altar), whereas bahiddha is something outside a point of reference or removed past a boundary. That is, interior/exterior are two aspects of a single thing, whereas inside/outside are two distinct things.

sn35.69:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ upasenaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.69:2.1.eng: When he said this, Sāriputta said to him,

sn35.69:2.2.pli: “na kho pana mayaṃ passāma āyasmato upasenassa kāyassa vā aññathattaṃ indriyānaṃ vā vipariṇāmaṃ.
sn35.69:2.2.eng: “But we don’t see any impairment in your body or deterioration of your faculties.

sn35.69:2.4.pli: ‘etha me, āvuso, imaṃ kāyaṃ mañcakaṃ āropetvā bahiddhā nīharatha.
sn35.69:2.4.eng: ‘Come, reverends, lift this body onto a cot and carry it outside

sn35.69:2.7.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, there may be an impairment in body or deterioration of faculties for someone who thinks:

sn35.69:2.8.eng: ‘I am the eye’ or ‘the eye is mine.’

sn35.69:2.9.pli: ahaṃ jivhāti vā mama jivhāti vā …
sn35.69:2.9.eng: Or ‘I am the ear … nose … tongue … body …’

sn35.69:2.10.pli: ahaṃ manoti vā mama mano’ti vā.
sn35.69:2.10.eng: Or ‘I am the mind’ or ‘the mind is mine.’

sn35.69:2.11.pli: Tassa, āvuso sāriputta, siyā kāyassa vā aññathattaṃ indriyānaṃ vā vipariṇāmo.

sn35.69:2.12.pli: Mayhañca kho, āvuso sāriputta, na evaṃ hoti:
sn35.69:2.12.eng: But I don’t think like that.

sn35.69:2.14.pli: ahaṃ jivhāti vā mama jivhāti vā …pe…

sn35.69:2.15.pli: ahaṃ manoti vā mama manoti vā’.

sn35.69:2.16.pli: Tassa mayhañca kho, āvuso sāriputta, kiṃ kāyassa vā aññathattaṃ bhavissati, indriyānaṃ vā vipariṇāmo”ti.
sn35.69:2.16.eng: So why would there be an impairment in my body or deterioration of my faculties?”

sn35.69:3.1.pli: Tathā hi panāyasmato upasenassa dīgharattaṃ ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayo susamūhato.
sn35.69:3.1.eng: “That must be because Venerable Upasena has long ago totally eradicated I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit.

sn35.69:3.2.pli: Tasmā āyasmato upasenassa na evaṃ hoti:
sn35.69:3.2.eng: That’s why it doesn’t occur to you:

sn35.69:3.3.eng: ‘I am the eye’ or ‘the eye is mine.’ Or ‘I am the ear …

sn35.69:3.4.pli: ahaṃ jivhāti vā mama jivhāti vā …pe…

sn35.69:3.5.pli: ahaṃ manoti vā mama mano’ti vā”ti.
sn35.69:3.5.eng: Or ‘I am the mind’ or ‘the mind is mine.’”

sn35.69:3.6.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmato upasenassa kāyaṃ mañcakaṃ āropetvā bahiddhā nīhariṃsu.
sn35.69:3.6.eng: Then those mendicants lifted Upasena’s body onto a cot and carried it outside.

sn35.69:3.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmato upasenassa kāyo tattheva vikiri;
sn35.69:3.7.eng: And his body was scattered right there

sn35.7:0.3.eng: The Interior as Impermanent in the Three Times

sn35.7:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the eye of the past and future is impermanent,

sn35.7:1.3.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītasmiṃ cakkhusmiṃ anapekkho hoti;
sn35.7:1.3.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple is not concerned with the eye of the past,

sn35.7:1.4.eng: they don’t look forward to enjoying the eye in the future,

sn35.7:1.5.pli: paccuppannassa cakkhussa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn35.7:1.5.eng: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye in the present.

sn35.7:1.10.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītāya jivhāya anapekkho hoti;

sn35.7:1.12.pli: paccuppannāya jivhāya nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn35.7:1.14.eng: mind of the past and future is impermanent,

sn35.7:1.16.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītasmiṃ manasmiṃ anapekkho hoti;
sn35.7:1.16.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple doesn’t worry about the mind of the past,

sn35.7:1.17.eng: they don’t look forward to enjoying the mind in the future,

sn35.7:1.18.pli: paccuppannassa manassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hotī”ti.
sn35.7:1.18.eng: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the mind in the present.”

sn35.70:0.3.eng: Upavāṇa on What is Apparent in the Present Life

sn35.70:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upavāṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe…
sn35.70:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Upavāṇa went up to the Buddha …

sn35.70:1.2.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā upavāṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn35.70:1.3.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘a teaching apparent in the present life’.
sn35.70:1.3.comm: “Apparent in this very life” (sandiṭṭhika) is one of the fundamental characteristics of the Dhamma, which are recited in the Pali itipi so formula to this day.

sn35.70:1.4.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti, akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti?
sn35.70:1.4.eng: In what way is the teaching apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”

sn35.70:2.1.pli: “Idha pana, upavāṇa, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā rūpappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti rūparāgappaṭisaṃvedī ca.
sn35.70:2.1.eng: “Upavāṇa, take a mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes. They experience both the sight and the desire for the sight.

sn35.70:2.2.pli: Santañca ajjhattaṃ rūpesu rāgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ rūpesu rāgo’ti pajānāti.
sn35.70:2.2.eng: There is desire for sights in them, and they understand that.

sn35.70:2.3.pli: Yaṃ taṃ, upavāṇa, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā rūpappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti rūparāgappaṭisaṃvedī ca.

sn35.70:2.4.pli: Santañca ajjhattaṃ rūpesu rāgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ rūpesu rāgo’ti pajānāti.

sn35.70:2.5.pli: Evampi kho, upavāṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhi …pe….
sn35.70:2.5.eng: this is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

sn35.70:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, upavāṇa, bhikkhu jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā rasappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti rasarāgappaṭisaṃvedī ca.
sn35.70:3.1.eng: Next, take a mendicant who hears … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.70:3.2.pli: Santañca ajjhattaṃ rasesu rāgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ rasesu rāgo’ti pajānāti.

sn35.70:3.3.pli: Yaṃ taṃ, upavāṇa, bhikkhu jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā rasappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti rasarāgappaṭisaṃvedī ca.

sn35.70:3.4.pli: Santañca ajjhattaṃ rasesu rāgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ rasesu rāgo’ti pajānāti. Evampi kho, upavāṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhi …pe….

sn35.70:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, upavāṇa, bhikkhu manasā dhammaṃ viññāya dhammappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammarāgappaṭisaṃvedī ca.
sn35.70:4.1.eng: Next, take a mendicant who knows an idea with their mind. They experience both the idea and the desire for the idea.

sn35.70:4.2.pli: Santañca ajjhattaṃ dhammesu rāgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ dhammesu rāgo’ti pajānāti.
sn35.70:4.2.eng: There is desire for ideas in them, and they understand that.

sn35.70:4.3.pli: Yaṃ taṃ, upavāṇa, bhikkhu manasā dhammaṃ viññāya dhammappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammarāgappaṭisaṃvedī ca.

sn35.70:4.4.pli: Santañca ajjhattaṃ dhammesu rāgaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ dhammesu rāgo’ti pajānāti.

sn35.70:4.5.pli: Evampi kho, upavāṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti …pe… paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhi …pe….
sn35.70:4.5.eng: this is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

sn35.70:5.1.pli: Idha pana, upavāṇa, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā rūpappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti, no ca rūparāgappaṭisaṃvedī.
sn35.70:5.1.eng: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes. They experience the sight but no desire for the sight.

sn35.70:5.2.pli: Asantañca ajjhattaṃ rūpesu rāgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ rūpesu rāgo’ti pajānāti.
sn35.70:5.2.eng: There is no desire for sights in them, and they understand that.

sn35.70:5.3.pli: Yaṃ taṃ, upavāṇa, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā rūpappaṭisaṃvedīhi kho hoti, no ca rūparāgappaṭisaṃvedī.

sn35.70:5.4.pli: Asantañca ajjhattaṃ rūpesu rāgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ rūpesu rāgo’ti pajānāti.

sn35.70:5.5.pli: Evampi kho, upavāṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti, akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhi …pe….
sn35.70:5.5.eng: this is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

sn35.70:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, upavāṇa, bhikkhu jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā rasappaṭisaṃvedīhi kho hoti, no ca rasarāgappaṭisaṃvedī. Asantañca ajjhattaṃ rasesu rāgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ rasesu rāgo’ti pajānāti …pe….
sn35.70:6.1.eng: Next, take a mendicant who hears … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.70:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, upavāṇa, bhikkhu manasā dhammaṃ viññāya dhammappaṭisaṃvedīhi kho hoti, no ca dhammarāgappaṭisaṃvedī.

sn35.70:7.2.pli: Asantañca ajjhattaṃ dhammesu rāgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ dhammesu rāgo’ti pajānāti.

sn35.70:7.3.pli: Yaṃ taṃ, upavāṇa, bhikkhu manasā dhammaṃ viññāya dhammappaṭisaṃvedīhi kho hoti, no ca dhammarāgappaṭisaṃvedī.
sn35.70:7.3.eng: Next, take a mendicant who knows an idea with their mind. They experience the idea but no desire for the idea.

sn35.70:7.4.pli: Asantañca ajjhattaṃ dhammesu rāgaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ dhammesu rāgo’ti pajānāti.
sn35.70:7.4.eng: There is no desire for ideas in them, and they understand that.

sn35.70:7.5.pli: Evampi kho, upavāṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti, akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
sn35.70:7.5.eng: Since this is so, this is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”

sn35.71:1.1.pli: “Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
sn35.71:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, anyone who doesn’t truly understand the six fields of contact’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape

sn35.71:1.2.pli: Avusitaṃ tena brahmacariyaṃ, ārakā so imasmā dhammavinayā”ti.
sn35.71:1.2.eng: has not completed the spiritual journey and is far from this teaching and training.”

sn35.71:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.71:2.1.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

sn35.71:2.2.comm: Commentary traces anassasaṁ (variant anassāsiṁ) to √nas (perish), which Digital Pali Dictionary rejects as “unviable”. It is, rather, the present participle of na assasati, “discouraged, unconsoled”.

sn35.71:2.3.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmī”ti.
sn35.71:2.3.eng: For I don’t truly understand the six fields of contact’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.”

sn35.71:3.2.pli: cakkhuṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassasī”ti?
sn35.71:3.2.eng: Do you regard the eye like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.71:5.1.pli: “Sādhu, bhikkhu, ettha ca te, bhikkhu, cakkhu ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ bhavissati.
sn35.71:5.1.eng: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the eye, you will truly see clearly with right wisdom that: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn35.71:5.1.comm: The Buddha encourages with the future tense, rather than the optative “should”. This is an example of his knowledge of where all paths leads.

sn35.71:5.2.eng: Just this is the end of suffering.

sn35.71:5.3.pli: jivhaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassasī”ti?
sn35.71:5.3.eng: Do you regard the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.71:7.3.pli: manaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassasī”ti?
sn35.71:7.3.eng: Do you regard the mind like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.71:9.1.pli: “Sādhu, bhikkhu, ettha ca te, bhikkhu, mano ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ bhavissati.
sn35.71:9.1.eng: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the mind, you will truly see clearly with right wisdom that: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn35.71:9.2.eng: Just this is the end of suffering.”

sn35.73:3.2.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.73:5.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.73:5.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.73:7.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.73:7.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.73:11.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.73:13.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.73:13.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.73:13.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.73:15.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, sotasmimpi nibbindati, ghānasmimpi nibbindati, jivhāyapi nibbindati, kāyasmimpi nibbindati, manasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.73:15.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn35.73:15.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.73:15.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.73:15.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.73:15.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.74:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.74:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, and said to him,

sn35.74:1.3.pli: “amukasmiṃ, bhante, vihāre aññataro bhikkhu navo appaññāto ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn35.74:1.3.eng: “Sir, in such and such a monastery there’s a mendicant who is junior and not well-known. He’s sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn35.74:1.4.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
sn35.74:1.4.eng: Please go to him out of sympathy.”

sn35.74:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā navavādañca sutvā gilānavādañca, “appaññāto bhikkhū”ti iti viditvā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami.
sn35.74:2.1.eng: When the Buddha heard that the mendicant was junior and ill, understanding that he was not well-known, he went to him.

sn35.74:2.2.pli: Addasā kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
sn35.74:2.2.eng: That mendicant saw the Buddha coming off in the distance

sn35.74:2.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn35.74:2.4.eng: The Buddha said to that monk,

sn35.74:2.5.eng: “It’s all right, mendicant, don’t get up.

sn35.74:2.6.eng: There are some seats spread out, I will sit there.”

sn35.74:2.7.eng: He sat on the seat spread out

sn35.74:2.8.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:

sn35.74:2.9.pli: “kacci te, bhikkhu, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti no abhikkamanti, paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no abhikkamo”ti?
sn35.74:2.9.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

sn35.74:3.1.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ, na yāpanīyaṃ, bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti no paṭikkamanti, abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no paṭikkamo”ti.
sn35.74:3.1.eng: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”

sn35.74:4.1.pli: “Kacci te, bhikkhu, na kiñci kukkuccaṃ, na koci vippaṭisāro”ti?
sn35.74:4.1.eng: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”

sn35.74:5.1.pli: “Taggha me, bhante, anappakaṃ kukkuccaṃ, anappako vippaṭisāro”ti.
sn35.74:5.1.eng: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”

sn35.74:6.1.pli: “Kacci pana taṃ, bhikkhu, attā sīlato upavadatī”ti?
sn35.74:6.1.eng: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”

sn35.74:7.1.pli: “Na kho maṃ, bhante, attā sīlato upavadatī”ti.
sn35.74:7.1.eng: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”

sn35.74:8.1.pli: “No ce kira te, bhikkhu, attā sīlato upavadati, atha kiñca te kukkuccaṃ ko ca vippaṭisāro”ti?
sn35.74:8.1.eng: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regret?”

sn35.74:9.1.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ, bhante, sīlavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn35.74:9.1.eng: “Because I understand that the Buddha has not taught the Dhamma merely for the sake of ethical purity.”

sn35.74:10.1.pli: “No ce kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sīlavisuddhatthaṃ mayā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāsi, atha kimatthaṃ carahi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
sn35.74:10.1.eng: “If that is so, what then do you understand to be the purpose of teaching the Dhamma?”

sn35.74:11.1.pli: “Rāgavirāgatthaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn35.74:11.1.eng: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of the fading away of greed.”
sn35.74:11.1.comm: The expression rāgavirāga plays on two senses of the word. The root sense of rāga is “dye” or “color”, especially red (cf. rajaka, MN 56:27.14) . From there it took on the sense “greed, lust, passion” which dominates in Pali. Thus rāgavirāga is both the “fading of color” and the “dispassion of passion”. It is a term for the quelling of harmful emotions (AN 2.31).

sn35.74:12.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, rāgavirāgatthaṃ mayā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāsi.
sn35.74:12.2.eng: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of the fading away of greed.

sn35.74:12.3.pli: Rāgavirāgattho hi, bhikkhu, mayā dhammo desito.
sn35.74:12.3.eng: For that is indeed the purpose.

sn35.74:12.5.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.74:16.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.74:16.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.74:18.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.74:18.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.74:18.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.74:20.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, sotasmimpi nibbindati …pe… manasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.74:20.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn35.74:20.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.74:20.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.74:20.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended … there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.74:21.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn35.74:21.2.pli: Attamano so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandi.
sn35.74:21.2.eng: Satisfied, that mendicant approved what the Buddha said.

sn35.74:21.3.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne tassa bhikkhuno virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
sn35.74:21.3.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in that mendicant:

sn35.74:21.4.eng: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”

sn35.75:1.2.eng: “Sir, in such and such a monastery there’s a mendicant who is junior and not well-known. He’s sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn35.75:1.3.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
sn35.75:1.3.eng: Please go to him out of sympathy.”

sn35.75:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā navavādañca sutvā gilānavādañca, “appaññāto bhikkhū”ti iti viditvā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami.
sn35.75:2.1.eng: When the Buddha heard that the mendicant was junior and ill, understanding that he was not well-known, he went to him.

sn35.75:2.2.pli: Addasā kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.

sn35.75:2.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:

sn35.75:2.5.eng: “It’s all right, mendicant, don’t get up.

sn35.75:2.7.pli: Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane. Nisajja kho bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn35.75:2.7.eng: He sat on the seat spread out and said to the mendicant,

sn35.75:2.8.pli: “kacci te, bhikkhu, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti no abhikkamanti, paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no abhikkamo”ti?
sn35.75:2.8.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

sn35.75:3.1.eng: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. …

sn35.75:3.2.pli: na kho maṃ, bhante, attā sīlato upavadatī”ti.
sn35.75:3.2.eng: I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”

sn35.75:4.1.pli: “No ce kira te, bhikkhu, attā sīlato upavadati, atha kiñca te kukkuccaṃ ko ca vippaṭisāro”ti?
sn35.75:4.1.eng: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regret?”

sn35.75:5.1.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ, bhante, sīlavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn35.75:5.1.eng: “Because I understand that the Buddha has not taught the Dhamma merely for the sake of ethical purity.”

sn35.75:6.1.pli: “No ce kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sīlavisuddhatthaṃ mayā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāsi, atha kimatthaṃ carahi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
sn35.75:6.1.eng: “If that is so, what then do you understand to be the purpose of teaching the Dhamma?”

sn35.75:7.1.pli: “Anupādāparinibbānatthaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn35.75:7.1.eng: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.”
sn35.75:7.1.comm: Here both sides of the upādāna metaphor are alive: Nibbana is the freedom of letting go all grasping at attachments; and it is the extinguishment of fuel that ignites the fire of suffering.

sn35.75:8.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, anupādāparinibbānatthaṃ mayā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāsi.
sn35.75:8.2.eng: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.

sn35.75:8.3.pli: Anupādāparinibbānattho hi, bhikkhu, mayā dhammo desito.
sn35.75:8.3.eng: For that is indeed the purpose.

sn35.75:9.2.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.75:11.9.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.75:11.9.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.75:13.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.75:15.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.75:17.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye … ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.75:17.5.pli: Yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.75:17.5.eng: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact.

sn35.75:17.6.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.75:17.6.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.75:17.7.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.

sn35.75:18.2.eng: Satisfied, that mendicant approved what the Buddha said.

sn35.75:18.3.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the mind of that mendicant was freed from defilements by not grasping.
